intro: Tragacantha pamphylica, commonly known as the Pamphylian tragacanth, is a flowering plant native to southern Turkey. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its distinctive yellow flowers and trifoliate leaves. The plant produces a gum resin, similar to other tragacanth species, which has been historically used in traditional medicine and as a natural adhesive. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing on rocky soils in mountainous regions. Its ecological role includes providing habitat and food for various insects and small animals.
